channel.title: Yet Another Programming Blog
channel.description: Recent content on Yet Another Programming Blog

item.title: Functional Programming
item.description: Clique aqui para ler a versão em Português This is a short introduction to functional programming using Elixir for examples, but you don’t need to know Elixir to understand them. History So, functional programming. It started in 1958 with Lisp by John McCarthy, it is a programming paradigm that’s gaining a lot of traction recently, since it makes programs more readable and easier to maintain, since it tries to treat computations as mathematical functions, causing no side effects.

item.title: Monads
item.description: Clique aqui para ler a versão em Português This is my shot at explaining monads. If I say something that’s not true, I encourage to send me an email correcting me. Monads are objects that may or may not return a value. Putting it in simple terms, monads means something can return either a value or nothing, or an arbitrary number of values. For example, using JavaScript: function monad(x) { if (x > 5) { return x; } return null; } monad() can return null or x, depending on the argument it receives.

item.title: Getting started with Programming
item.description: Clique aqui para ler a versão em Português The Struggle When you are getting started with programming, you may be confused with which programming language you should learn (even though you are not even sure what those are). So I’ll give you some help. Stop trying to do that! You are spending precious time you could be studying or programming! Just pick whatever language you think you may like. If you have no idea of which one you should start with, I’ll give you some tips.

item.title: About me
item.description: Clique aqui para ler a versão em Português So. First blog post. Let’s get the boring part out of the way, I’m a highschooler that loves tech (I know how generic that sound) living in Brazil. I started programming when I was 13 years old, when I had my first contact with Linux, with a Raspberry Pi. Then, some time later, I wanted to do some things with GPIO so I introduced myself to Python (which is still my best language).
